title: The Importance of Preoperative NLR, PLR, and MPV Values in Predicting the Risk of Complications in Colorectal Peritoneal Carcinomatosis

The Importance of Preoperative NLR, PLR, and MPV Values in Predicting the Risk of Complications in Colorectal Peritoneal Carcinomatosis 
Background
Neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), platelet-to-lymphocyte ratio (PLR), and mean platelet volume (MPV) measurements can be easily assessed in most hospital laboratories. Our aim is to emphasize the importance of preoperative inflammatory parameters such as NLR, PLR, and MPV in predicting postoperative complications in patients undergoing surgery for colorectal peritoneal carcinomatosis (CRC PC).
Methods
Patients operated for CRC PC were evaluated. Demographic data, NLR, PLR, and MPV values were calculated using the following formulas: NLR = (absolute neutrophil count)/(total lymphocyte count), PLR = (total lymphocyte count)/(total platelet count) × 100, MPV = mean platelet volume calculated by dividing platelet crit (PCT) by total platelet count.
Results
A total of 196 patients with CRC PC were included in the study. A statistically significant relationship was observed between NLR, PLR, MPV, and OS.
